text: It's so good to see you I'm so happy to be here My name is Antonia and this is my friend Savik And if you've been here since the last talk you may have already heard a very good talk on Edge So we're going to give another maybe less good one also on Edge But we're going to show you hopefully a demo so you're going to see it in We want to start with a little bit of an introduction on Edge computing for those who may be uninitiated to it What it is and how it's used in the industry today And then we want to talk about a specific project which is called kube edge And we will demo it for you as well So yeah let's go What is Edge computing So according to Gartner's glossary Edge computing is part of a distributed computing topology where information processing is located close to the edge where things and people produce or consume that OK so how does that look like in practice So in the slide you can see a factory at the And then you can also see a couple of clouds in the sky And a factory is a place where among other things information is produced or data in this case And the machinery that produces such data would be things like sensors or actuators or other machinery Now we refer to these kinds of machines as IIoT devices where IIoT is the industrial Internet of So traditionally we would send all of this data up to the cloud for processing However this can be quite slow or it can be really expensive to do or sometimes it will just be not possible to do at all So in this case we introduced this nice additional layer that you see here which we call the edge It is between the cloud and the And as you can see there is a couple of machines here maybe some service You have to think about these as being physically close to the machines as being in the same network as these machines So why would you want to do this now There are a couple of reasons actually and here's four for you So latency So maybe your edge device is a self driving car You want to make a really quick decision Sometimes you might not want there to be any latency in case you might die So the other one that you might care about is bandwidth So you might have a lot of raw data that your processes are emitting and you need to pre process them before you stream them anywhere Then there's autonomy That's a big one actually So in case your factory is somewhere in the mountains or somewhere else where the network is really bad you don't want things to just not work because you don't have network So this is pretty important the last one is kind of self explanatory but privacy You don't want to put certain data into the cloud or also there can be a regulation where you're just not allowed to do it right So there are lots of fields where these things and others would make you want to use edge computing IoT retail smart cities telco healthcare space There's not an exhaustive list There are new use cases basically being added every day But what we're interested in right now is how Kubernetes could help us with this All right so we talked about edge computing and let's see where Kubernetes fits and why we might need it there So there are a few challenges to edge computing like running workloads at the edge is different than running workloads in a data center or in So we might need to scale to thousands of small nodes on devices which often scatter across remote locations Those locations will have bad connectivity will be resource constrained Regardless of that we still need to ensure that these things get patched and updated consistently just like any other Kubernetes cluster Hence why we're back to this scale connectivity and updates challenges that we need to And this is where Kubernetes already solved these challenges in traditional IT already So by being declarative so you have desired states and then the system will make it real It is portable so you can run the same things whether you're in the cloud or at the edge And it is automated through the use of reconciliation loops and controllers So humans don't have to do the work the machines do it for us And it is the same operational model as in we have the same familiar Kubernetes API that we already use in the cloud at the edge So you can use like GitOps and all these things for our edge scheduling However vanilla Kubernetes works on the assumption that stable networking is a given which is not always the case at the edge And this is where KubeEdge comes into play So KubeEdge is a project that was started in 2018 by Huawei in China with their stated mission to extend Kubernetes at the edge and to IoT devices So the core features and objectives are to offer a standard Kubernetes API handle unreliable networking and management of devices through the concept of device twins which we'll talk a little bit more in a bit So here you have the timeline of the evolution of the KubeEdge project but last year it graduated in October as a CNC accredited project And a couple success stories of KubeEdge Like this one is China when they overhauled 85  of the country for their electronic toll collection system on the highways So the old system would be a bunch of like highway toll plazas with humans collecting fare from the So that would be slow and manual However it was replaced by these overhead gantries that you can see on screen with like mounted cameras that would perform license plate recognition And this thing would run on over 100 000 KubeEdge nodes running 500 000 edge applications And just to put it into perspective this would generate and process around 300 million data points every day And it is said to have improved traffic efficiency at toll stations over 10 times And the other pretty cool one is the first cloud native edge satellites So the application for this is to address flood prevention and disaster mitigation So originally a flood happens The area is imaged by the satellites The data is sent back down to Earth And a human a person would compile a report for that It's pretty slow pretty manual labor And also in mountainous regions sometimes you would have a cloud cover So the images would be And the bandwidth would be wasted which we can't really afford anymore So in 2021 China launched the first satellites which was connected by a KubeEdge And this thing would embed as well would still embed a small AI model So when the area is imaged the AI model processes and identifies the cloud cover analyzes the water level and determines whether the data is worth transmitting downlink to the ground station If it is then there is a more powerful model that will process the data and do the same work but in an automated way And it's said that disaster response time was reduced from days to hours And the data transmission was reduced by around 90 percent So this is quite a significant success story If you want to see more of these there's this website like the public one case studies You can check out this a lot more But these two are the main ones And now we're going to move on to architecture Okay so enough about satellites This is the fun part where I get to show you a bunch of diagrams Before I'm going to go into any sort of detail I want to give a little bit of a higher level overview of what KubeEdge would look like on your cluster So you might recognize this cloud edge device trifecta here from the earlier slides And if you look at the cloud layer you have to think of this as not being in a cloud provider necessarily but this could be on premises as well Basically it could be any Kubernetes cluster And on the cloud layer you can see a component that is called the cloud core And this is the entry point from the Kubernetes API into the So basically all of the communication would go through this cloud core And then on the edge layer you see an edge core This edge core runs on every edge node So you see one here However there can be thousands of them And again this could be tall stations or satellites or something like that The edge nodes join your Kubernetes cluster by connecting to the cloud core And they actually show up as normal Kubernetes nodes They do have a special label on them so you can schedule your workloads accordingly And the edge core is installed on your machine as a single binary So the edge core talks to the device layer via MQTT And it also talks to local applications APIs and so on via HTTP Then on the device layers where you find the actual devices so sensors robots cameras what have you And KubeEdge offers also a framework which allows you to represent these as Kubernetes custom resources As a side note you can see that I marked the Kubernetes API related streams here in blue And then the ones related to devices in red So maybe it's going to make the slides easier to follow I don't know Let's talk about the cloud core first So the cloud core is installed in your cluster as a Helm chart And you can use an upstream CLI tool that is called KeyADM for that You can also do some other fun things with KeyADM The cloud core has a couple of The first one you can see here is the cloud hub which is the messaging broker of the cloud core So this is opening a secure persistent channel to each of the edge hubs And it does that via WebSocket or even quick protocols The red and blue controllers you can see do two different things So the first one is the edge controller which propagates changes to workloads running at the edge from the Kubernetes API to the And in the opposite direction it will report back things like statuses and events and so on And then the device controller reconciles the device CRs So this syncs between Kubernetes custom resource and any managed devices you might have And actually bundling all of the communication in kube edge through this cloud core has a couple of So the first one you get is load reduction This is done by aggregating updates So you don't actually send all of the updates from all the 100 000 nodes or whatever You will aggregate them so as not to overload your Kubernetes API server that much Then you also get resilience across flaky networks which is done by incremental updates So as I mentioned some of your nodes might disconnect sometimes for a And then when they reconnect you don't actually again flood the Kubernetes API server with all these updates But instead there is like an incremental update process that happens So you can integrate edge into any Kubernetes cluster theoretically using this mechanism And it has been shown that 100 000 nodes were added like that Now the edge core this one has a memory footprint of around 70 megabytes And the edge core also has an edge hub So this is as you might think the counterpart to the cloud hub On the other side it links to the It connects via WebSocket or And it will route the messages from the cloud to the correct edge modules It also reports back the node and device status And it handles things like keep alive and routing messages also within the edge core There are two important modules that you can see here as well which both work with the local state So the first one is the metamanager which is a cache and message processor This means that it will store data like pod state config map contents and so on in this local database which is SQLite database And this is so that in case your node disconnects it will still work The other one you can see is the device twin which keeps track of the state of your devices So it manages the attributes and status And it will sync that information to applications that run locally but it will also sync it to the cloud Then on the lower left there you have the thing called HD And you can think about HD as being the cuplet of the edge core So this will manage the lifecycle of And it will talk to the container runtime You can run workers on the edge nodes just as you would in the cloud And it will also actually handle some other resources that are cached locally like config maps and secrets and so on Also all of the communication that happens within the edge node goes through this common messaging protocol which is called Beehive which is something that is original to QBadge You get two buses on top of those The event bus integrates with MQTT And then you also have the service bus which provides HTTP communication Now you can also see in this picture the container runtime which I already said is running workloads under the control of HD I always have to remember So then you get the mappers which we will actually talk about the mappers a little bit later But they basically translate between device protocols and QBadge basically MQTT And all of these components here together there's quite a lot of them they will allow nodes to keep running workloads managing devices doing all these things whether they are currently connected or not So let's talk about devices a little bit more Yeah So at this point we have an edge node which is joined to our Kubernetes cluster This is already a very valid use case because we can scale workloads on this thing We can connect it to Flux GitOps all that But we can go a bit further by leveraging the IoT capabilities of QBadge And this is where we get back into the IoT territory And over there it's all about protocols So I'm talking about communication protocols These standardize how data is collected transmitted and exposed in our environment So an IoT device is just a thing that generates data So they would be from various sources like cameras sensors and such And they will be exposed on one of these protocols for There are quite a few more than that But think like an IKEA temperature that you connect to a home assistant via ZigBee This is kind of the same idea except here we want that data to be consumed by QBadge So this is where mappers come into play So these mappers are translators between the physical world and the QBadge world And in the industry we usually refer to them as adapters like HiveMQ Edge That's what they call it That's what they call them sorry However QBadge calls them mappers because they map a protocol to something that QBadge would likely understand And we can visualize this a bit more clearly on screen here On the right hand side we have the hardware devices that generate said data On the left hand side we have QBadge And in the middle we have these mappers So these are containers running on our edge nodes And they have like this ZigBee dongle for They know how to talk to these things And then they will convey the data back to QBadge via the messaging protocol There are already a few mappers upstream that you can leverage like these ones I think already available But there is a framework to build your own in And once we have these mappers running we need to get these hardware devices into QBadge So there are a bunch of custom resource definitions that we install with the hand charts But the two main ones that we want to talk about here are the device models and the device instance So the device model is the type of hardware device And the instance is the thing that we will deploy in our environment And here we have a slightly simple example here with the Advantech LM6017 I've never seen or even touched one of these I just Googled it It seems pretty simple So it has eight channels to which you can add sensors Modbus register address for each of these compatible Ethernet so you can access it on IP and port And just for the sake of showing you what it looks like so on the left hand side we have the custom resource of that device model So we have a channel We have a property for each of these channels So we would have eight of these only two on screen because we have limited space and a protocol which is Modbus in case we have a mapper with the protocol Modbus registered in our edge core And yeah that thing on the right is just an extract from the user guide where you would find the Modbus addresses for each of these channels And then in our device instance we get pretty much the same things We have a device model ref that references the device model we just created config data on how to access this thing on IP and port And then on the right hand side we specify the Modbus register addresses With you can add push methods if you want to push the data to an IoT platform or something like that But enough theory Let's get into the fun part which might be not so fun part for us But let's cross fingers I'm just going to move this thing So the demo here is another picture of me raising my hands here This is just to give you an idea of what the app is actually doing behind the scenes because we run this thing in a container so there's no visual feedback But we have a camera here which is connected via USB to this wonderful Raspberry Pi This Raspberry Pi runs Cube Edge and is connected to a client cluster on my laptop via this Ethernet cable here It's quite a bit to set up when we do a talk And this Python app that we run on this Raspberry Pi runs the Google MediaPipe framework which allows you to use OpenCV to detect human postures So here we extrapolate a shoulder line with your limb parts or whatever it's called And when a hand is detected above the shoulder line it will be considered as So you can see there there are two raised hands So the slight limitation on this thing is that there is one shoulder line and there are many shoulders here in this room so we can only work with say the front row here So you guys are going to have to play ball I'm But first I'm going to install this thing because for some reason I decided to install the mapper and stuff during the So here we can take a look at our cluster so I don't know if it's big enough So you can see that we have the control plane node which is our kind node and then we have the Raspberry Pi If we describe the Raspberry Pi you can see that it's just a normal regular Kubernetes node with labels request limits all these things The label would be what you would use to schedule workloads like Antonio said And if I look at the pods currently running you can see well there's quite a lot going on but we don't have the mapper or the app or anything running So we're going to install that just now So I'm going to start by installing the And now I'm going to check I don't have mirroring so I have to check that Okay our mapper has started Then I am going to install the CRDs I'm going to start with the model And then the instance which references that model And now if I look at this device instance we can find pretty much the same information I showed you earlier We have the protocol the config data how to access the MQTT broker etc And we have an initial value of 0 raise 10 in our device twin that you can see here And now I am going to install the actual app that will do the hand detection This one And that thing should light up blue hopefully It's blue Yeah nice Okay so I just need to port forward Grafana real quick And I need to bring Grafana to this screen Apparently someone is raising his hand No All right so it's a bit finicky We've not proven this thing to work 100  with audiences Joe shoulder line Higher I was trained So it's kind of like we always have to fiddle with the camera placement and stuff So can we get something going here don't have broad enough shoulders Yeah Antonia do you like humanities That's a yes or no question It's a yes This is a binary okay Okay I might be moving a little bit I'm going to try and leave it there I'm going to try and leave it there You can see So feel free to raise your hands as you want You're going to have to go a bit higher Now let's take a quick look at what it looks like So here I'm going to bring up a couple windows here So at the top left we have the actual device twin which is a Kubernetes resource So whatever is registered by Kube Edge in the Kubernetes API So it goes to red when it changes value And the top right is the MQTT mapper the MQTT broker So we subscribe to the topic directly So instant feedback from the app At the bottom we have the logs from the MQTT mapper So whenever we have a change you can see that there is a slight delay between the Kube Edge CR and the actual MQTT publishing This is because of this kind of edge core dance everything that goes back to the Kubernetes API So it's actually picking up a few raised hands now and again Our camera is not Army grade so it's kind of Amazon grade camera So apologies for that But we do have values that change on You can see that it's not recorded For the sake of time I'm going to move on a little bit and talk about the setup just now So we can find the same three layer diagram that Antoinette talked about earlier So at the top we have the cloud parts which is the can cluster running on my laptop which represents your cloud data center on premise Kubernetes cluster where you would run the cloud core We have the edge parts which is the Raspberry Pi So basically Kube Edge That's also where we run the mapper in our case And at the bottom the device is the Raspberry Pi and the USB webcam So this is obviously a serial demo a real world scenario you would have proper cameras that would use IP protocols like ONVIF and processing would be done directly in the Talking about mapper so the way this thing works is that Python app whenever it detects a raised hand will publish a message to the MQTT broker The mapper subscribes to said topic When there is a new message it will update the Kube Edge custom resource the device twin and it will export it on the metrics endpoint which is created by Prometheus and exposed by Grafana which is what you saw earlier with the big number changing This is not great This is what we do for these things just to have a big number change when we raise our hands But in real life you would push to a time series database or publish to an IoT solution that would do the processing for us You can find that demo here If you scan that QR code you will have access to that GenSwarm repo You will find the MQTT mapper You will find the Python app the custom
